Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Maintain passenger safety and provide assistance during service.
Situation2: The passenger emergency alarm has been activated due to a medical emergency in the train.
Story: I was just about to send a quick text to my mom, something simple—“Hi, Ma, hope you and Dad are well”—when the shrill emergency alarm blared through the subway car. My heart jumped. I glanced at the message, half-typed, thumb hovering over the send button. I knew my parents worried if I didn’t check in, especially on weekends. They always said, “Just let us know you’re okay.” But now, the intercom crackled with urgency: “Medical emergency in car three.” I could already see passengers looking around, anxious, expecting me to act. My training kicked in—safety first, immediate response, every second counts. But my phone buzzed again, a new message from my dad: “Everything alright?” I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My family needed reassurance, but so did the people on my train. I stood frozen for a moment, torn between the duty to my parents and the responsibility to my passengers, feeling the pressure of both roles collide inside me.
